advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future.... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A TO7 from Thomson fills the empty cells"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"MO5. Adventure built-in"<br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture from an early advert published in january 1983 is very interesting (the TO-7 was just released then). The text below it said "Hours of entertainment...". But when you look more carefully at the software boxes you realise that they are fake! Only the two extreme boxes are real, but still shows the same game title "3-D TIC-TAC TOE"! So there is only one game presented here! The photograph was surely taken at an early development stage... <br><br> Even the name of the computer written on top of the boxes: "TOM 7" (Tele Ordinateur Multimedia?) seems to be an early name for the TO-7... <br><br> Hours of entertainment they said...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-502 was also called the Diabolik in France...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1987<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...This elegant little machine takes family computing into new dimensions of creativity, excitement and productivity. It outruns and outguns office PCs as a business multi-tasker, performing a deskful of different jobs simultaneously at over 7 million steps per second in realtime... </font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-60</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from a Commodore brochure.<br> Notice that the girl seems not to be interested at all in the computer...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"There music puts in it"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Sony HIT BIT 700f was the successor of the Sony HIT BIT 500. It met the MSX 2 standard.
It was sold as a semiprofessional computer; it came with a program on disk called HiBrid, which can be seen as a graphical shell around MSX-DOS. It had a saved CMOS memory, which held time, date, password or screen definition.
It also came with a MSX-DOS floppy, the MSX operating system, made by Microsoft, which looks like CP/M.
Ewout van Duursen reports: This computer has 256 KB RAM. But it only uses 64 KB in MSX-DOS. This was the only MSX2 on which you could play "Nemisis 2" from a disc ("Cracked from cartridge of coarse"). The memory was divided in 4 banks of 64 KB, Which where divided in 16 KB. The first 16 KB was used for BIOS. The next 16 KB was used for MSX-Basic. The next two banks where "free", except for the last couples of bytes. You could switch banks by "peeking" at adress &hFFFF. To play most games you had to peek 255,-1 for proper memory configuration.
More information from Bramman: ? All hitbit series had a country code. The HB700f was the US version. I had a HBF700-D with a german keyboard. ? The exact peek for games was poke -1,255. Which was irritating, because all other MSX's in Holland used Poke -1,170 (mostly Philips MSX's). On that peek the HB-700 rebooted, for every copied game the autoexec.bas had to be changed ;) ? The 256 KB RAM was called 256 Memory Mapper. It was built-in the HB-700, but you could buy a separate one as a cartridge. ? The machine was supplied with a GUI, installed separatly from the disk. This Gui looked alot like the Atari and Apple GUI's. ? The MSX-DOS was in ROM. Normal MSX's I've seen had MSX-dos on a disk. On this one you could switch to normal MSX-basic with a command.
Manuel Bilderbeek corrects and specifies: - MSX-DOS and other OS's are always loaded from disk, never from ROM except for a few rare Russian Yamaha machines that have CP/M in ROM. - MSX-DOS can only handle 64kB RAM, because of the Z80 and CP/M. - There's no such thing as 4 banks of 64kB RAM, unless the author means the physical RAM chips, but I don't know about that. - This machine contains indeed 256kB RAM, and as is the case with all MSX machines with more than 64kB, it uses the memory mapper mechanism, which works with blocks of 16kB that can be switched. - Under MSX-BASIC operation, the lower 32kB of the Z80 addressing space have the BIOS and BASIC ROM switched in, as with all MSX machines. - Address 0xFFFF is not for switching banks but for selecting the secundary slot of that slot. And one does not PEEK there to do that, but one POKEs. - The POKE that is mentioned should be POKE -1, 255. Here -1 is the same as 0xFFFF. This is to select the sub slot (3) with the RAM (memory mapper) in slot 3. Some old/bad software fails to select the RAM and hence this needs to be done from BASIC before loading. There's also a generic POKE to 0xFFFF to select the right subslot with the RAM that works on any MSX. - There never was a US version of this machine. - The 700F is the French version. The P is the PAL (international) version. D is the German version indeed. - Many external memory mapper cartridges to expand the RAM were sold. As you can see, most of this info is also valid for many other MSX machines.

emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.

computer.graphics: 9 graphic modes, the most used is 256 x 212 with 256 colors
